Modern pagans have faced a variety of challenges in trying to reconcile ancestral traditions with modern values. One challenge is the fact that many of these traditions are rooted in pre-modern or even prehistoric societies, which can make them difficult to understand or relate to in a modern context.

Another challenge is the fact that many of these traditions involve practices, beliefs, or symbols that may be seen as exclusionary or offensive to certain groups of people, such as women or LGBTQ individuals. This can lead to tension between pagans and these other communities, and can make it difficult for pagans to find acceptance in wider society.

To overcome these challenges, many modern pagans have sought to reinterpret or adapt their ancestral traditions to better fit modern values and sensibilities. For example, some have emphasized the ecological aspect of paganism and incorporated environmentalism and sustainability into their practice. Others have sought to challenge patriarchal or heteronormative aspects of traditional paganism and make the faith more inclusive of marginalized groups.

Additionally, many pagans have sought to engage with wider society and educate others about their beliefs and practices, in order to dispel misconceptions and promote greater understanding and acceptance. This can involve public rituals, workshops, and other educational events, as well as outreach to other faith communities and social justice organizations.
